context: At the end of a ride
expected_response: No, I couldn't possibly. Please, let me pay for your service.
cultural_notes: Persian cultural norm expects passengers to insist on paying despite driver's offer

context: After watching a movie, at concession stand
user_utterance: I got this one, you paid last time.
expected_response: No, please let me pay. You always pay for everything.
cultural_notes: One is expected to insist on paying the bill even after a refusal

context: Student has finished presentation, beginning examination
user_utterance: I suggest you start first since you are the expert in this field.
expected_response: No, no, you should go first. I defer to your expertise.
cultural_notes: Expected to hesitate to speak first when in presence of higher status

user_utterance: You're very intelligent and talented at chess.
expected_response: Oh no, I'm not that good. You played very well too.
cultural_notes: When receiving a compliment, should downplay it to sound modest

context: At a restaurant, after finishing meal
user_utterance: Let me pay for dinner tonight.
expected_response: No, no, I insist on paying. You paid last time we went out.
cultural_notes: Friends are expected to insist on paying to show generosity

context: In a work meeting, discussing project leadership
user_utterance: You should lead this project since you have more experience.
expected_response: No, you're much more qualified. I think you should take the lead.
cultural_notes: Expected to defer to others even when qualified for a position

context: At a family gathering, being offered food
user_utterance: Please, have some more of this delicious food.
expected_response: No, thank you, I'm already full. But it was absolutely wonderful.
cultural_notes: Expected to politely decline food offers while praising the food

context: At an academic conference, discussing research
user_utterance: Your research is groundbreaking and innovative.
expected_response: Oh, you're too kind. Your work is much more impressive than mine.
cultural_notes: Expected to deflect compliments and return them to the speaker

context: Customer is buying items, shop owner offers discount
user_utterance: For you, I'll give a special price.
expected_response: No, please charge the regular price. I don't want to trouble you.
cultural_notes: Expected to refuse special treatment or discounts to avoid burdening others

user_utterance: You're the expert, whatever you recommend is fine.
expected_response: No, this is your decision. I can only provide information and recommendations.
cultural_notes: Even experts are expected to defer to patient/family decision-making

expected_response: Of course! I'm here to help. What do you need?
cultural_notes: In emergencies, direct response is expected without taarof

context: Important business decision needs to be made
user_utterance: We need to decide on this contract today.
expected_response: Yes, let's discuss the terms and reach an agreement.
cultural_notes: Business contexts often require direct communication without taarof
